channel.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
channel.description: If you had to pick one aspect of running and managing a private server community (as in developing a server for others to play), in the eyes of the owner, as the most important aspect to focus on, which aspect would you choose? [size=1pt]Yes, I am probing you all for information.[/size]

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

I don’t think it’s so black and white.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

You’re either in it for the money or you’re not. So be in it for the money.

Read full topic

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

Listening and being fair are definitely key words there. It’s no use strutting your powers around whenever they are needed (or not needed). Speak to and treat them as if you were a regular player.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

mopman_sucks:

hamachi

Lmao.

On-Topic: Listening to your players, updating content, adding new content & being fair.

Off-Topic: Your light chaser game is a pain in the ass.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

  1. Choosing staff who aren’t 12 and fucking ban everyone that they personally dislike, reason being that you can have fully working castle wars, but it’s useless if the mod on the loosing team gets butt hurt and bans half the other team.
  2. Semi - Unique content, I can go though the same generic RS motions endlessly, but at least have some things unique like a home besides edgevile, etc.
  3. Not putting your servers name n everything, i.e
    “Welcome to name, pk for namepoints, visit the offical name’s site - name.com thank u 4 playing name btw”
    Just annoying

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

If you’re running a server, the term ‘Donation’ should almost never be mentioned. Offering rewards (at least big ones) is also a stupid idea. I hate the people that host their server specifically for receiving these payments, which is why I don’t believe the Sponsored Servers spots should even exist. This community is supposed to be the pulse of the RSPS drive, yet we don’t even promote development when all of the traffic tends to just head over to those spots anyway.

If accepting donations, you just need to make the players aware that you do. Maybe offer a new section on the forums, a skillcape or custom item, or something small in-game, but don’t go around every part of the game and make it seem like you’re desperate for money.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

mopman_sucks:

hamachi

True old school pioneering there.

[quote=“Chassy13, post:14, topic:443373”]My main in focus in developing a server is to keep the players entertained. A constant flow of updates is always good. I like to have them play around with new content that has never been seen on another server before.

Also as you have said, keeping them happy. If multiple players are complaining about a glitch or a recent update, I will do my best to fix them as fast as possible. If a player has an issue with their account or something in-game, I’ll drop anything I’m working on and will attempt to fix it for them.[/quote]
I think that’s the best attitude to have. If the players know you’d drop your work just to help them out, that would make them feel special. Although, sometimes if you get too friendly they expect it a little too much, not understanding there are others too, and then you have to think of a way to tell them to stop without hurting their trust in you.

I’ve helped manage a well known server in the past, and the owner was really arrogant. He wouldn’t take the time to handle the problems with player’s accounts (as he was the only one who could sort it), and he’d be away for weeks at a time. He expected donations and players, without giving the customer service.

This is what lead me here.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

My main in focus in developing a server is to keep the players entertained. A constant flow of updates is always good. I like to have them play around with new content that has never been seen on another server before.

Also as you have said, keeping them happy. If multiple players are complaining about a glitch or a recent update, I will do my best to fix them as fast as possible. If a player has an issue with their account or something in-game, I’ll drop anything I’m working on and will attempt to fix it for them.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

I agree with you both. I think what makes a server is ultimately the players. And that all depends on how you, the owner, treat the players and handle their requests.

Come to think of it, everything else should just coincide if you earn and maintain the trust of your community.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Sinned, post:4, topic:443373”]Sorry I didn’t explain it very well. For someone who is developing a server, and creating a community for their server, what do you think is the single most important aspect to focus on?

For instance: constant flow of updates, unique content, concentrating on player issues, etc. etc., whatever you can think of.[/quote]
I can’t focus on one, but these two intertwine I suppose:

Listen to players and their desires
=Update often

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server

item.title: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

All aspects are the most important. Think of them as parts of a bridge that uses an arch way. Each arch peace is an aspect of the server.

if you put your cards onto one aspect you will end up failing. Even if you can keep a good player base, you cannot continue if you have no income to sustain it. Say with the income, or updates, you have to be able to find a balance so that you can keep your players happy, but also be able to deliver great content and also great support in all cases that can come up.

Read full topic
item.source: The Most Important Aspect of Running a Private Server
